block.p: ATTRACTIONS
Museums and Sites

AMERICAN MUSEUM OF THE MOVING IMAGE, 34-12 36th Street, at 35th Avenue, Astoria, Queens. Exhibitions include ''Behind the Screen,'' a permanent display with more than 1,000 artifacts that illustrate the production, marketing and exhibition of moving images. The set of Monk's Cafe from ''Seinfeld'' is on display. ''Ride Lonesome: A Budd Boetticher Retrospective,'' through Sunday. Tomorrow at 2 p.m., ''The Rise and Fall of Legs Diamond'' (1960); at 4 p.m., ''Buchanan Rides Alone'' (1958) and ''The Long Shadow'' (1961). Sunday at 2 p.m., ''The Tall T'' (1957), featuring a dialogue with the filmmaker; at 5 p.m., ''Comanche Station'' (1960), introduced by Mr. Boetticher. ''Repertory Nights: New Prints of Classic Movies,'' tomorrow and Sunday at 6:30 p.m., Roman Polanski's ''Chinatown'' (1974). All activities are free with museum admission unless otherwise indicated. Admission: $8.50; the elderly and students, $5.50; ages 5 to 18, $4.50; 4 and under, free. Information: (718) 784-0077.

AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY, Central Park West and 79th Street. The Arthur Ross Terrace, a new one-acre public space, has recently opened, with the same hours as the museum. ''Fighting Dinosaurs: New Discoveries From Mongolia,'' featuring one of the most famous fossil finds in the world; through Oct. 29. ''Mongolia Observed: Photographs Present and Past,'' featuring 40 color images by Robert Peck and black-and-white photographs from the 1920's and 30's by the explorer Ray Chapman Andrews. Through Dec. 30. Imax films are ''To Be an Astronaut'' and ''Dolphins.'' In the Imax Theater tonight and tomorrow night at 9, ''Laser Aerosmith in 3-D''; at 10, ''Laser Led Zeppelin.'' Laser show tickets: $12. Museum hours: Sundays through Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 8:45 p.m. Admission (suggested donation): $10 for adults; $7.50 for students and the elderly; $6 for children. Combination tickets are available. Information: (212) 769-5100; advance tickets: (212) 769-5200.

AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY'S ROSE CENTER FOR EARTH AND SPACE, Central Park West at 81st Street. This 333,500-square-foot, seven-floor, 120-foot-high exhibition and research center includes the new Hayden Planetarium, the Cullman Hall of the Universe and the Gottesman Hall of Planet Earth. The Hayden Planetarium contains the Space Theater, presenting ''Passport to the Universe,'' and the Big Bang Theater, featuring narrated visual and audio effects simulating the beginning of the universe. ''Starry Nights: Fridays Under the Sphere,'' with the Jimmy Heath Quartet, at 6 to 8 p.m., with cash bar and tapas. ''Full Moon: Apollo Mission Photographs of the Lunar Landscape,'' from NASA's Apollo missions to the moon; through January. Hours: Sundays through Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays to 8:45 p.m. Space shows run throughout the day. Admission (suggested donation) to the American Museum of Natural History, which includes the Rose Center: $10; for students and the elderly, $7.50; children 12 and under, $6; under 2, free. Admission to the museum, the Rose Center and the Hayden Planetarium space show: $19; students and the elderly, $14; children 12 and under, $11.50; under 2, free. Information: (212) 769-5100. Reservations: (212) 769-5200.

MOUNT VERNON HOTEL MUSEUM, formerly the Abigail Adams Smith Museum, 421 East 61st Street, Manhattan. The structure, built in 1799 as the carriage house for Abigail Adams and Col. William Smith, was the Mount Vernon Hotel in the 1830's. Sixth annual Designers' Fare showcasing the work of noted interior designers and landscape designers for the benefit of the museum, today through Oct. 11. Hours: Fridays through Sundays, Tuesdays, Wednesdays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. (except Oct. 3, when it closes at 5 p.m.)); Mondays and Thursdays, 11 a.m. to 8 p.m. Admission: $10; $8 for students with identification, the elderly and museum members. ''A Taste of the Collection,'' early 19th-century silver, glass and ceramics typically found in American homes during that period; through Jan. 7. Hours: guided tours every half-hour beginning at 11 a.m.; last tour is at 3:30 p.m. Tuesdays through Sundays, 11 a.m. to 4 p.m.; closed Mondays. Admission: $4; students and the elderly, $3; 12 and under, free. Information: (212) 838-6878.

MUSEUM OF TELEVISION AND RADIO, 25 West 52nd Street, Manhattan. A collection of taped radio and television broadcasts and exhibitions in other media, including drawings, posters and photographs. ''Madison Avenue Goes to Washington: The History of Presidential Campaign Advertising,'' historically significant presidential commercials created between 1952 and 1996; Tuesdays through Sundays at 2 p.m., through Nov. 12. ''Monster in the Box: Horror on Television,'' series focusing on five decades of the genre; Fridays at 7 p.m. and Saturdays and Sundays at 4 p.m., Thursdays at 6 p.m.; through Dec. 10. Episodes through Sunday: tonight at 7; tomorrow and Sunday at 4 p.m., (1959); Steven Spielberg's ''Eyes'' (1969); Jacques Tourneur's ''Twilight Zone'' episode ''Night Call'' (1964) and Robert Zemeckis's ''Tales From the Crypt'' episode ''Yellow'' (1991). Museum hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, noon to 6 p.m.; Thursdays until 8 p.m. On Fridays the theater is open until 9. Admission: $6; students and the elderly, $4; 12 and under, $3. Information: (212) 621-6800.
Gardens

BROOKLYN BOTANIC GARDEN, 900 Washington Avenue, Prospect Heights. The Japanese Hill and Pond Garden is open and guided tours are available. A children's art show of drawings and paintings in the Steinhardt Gallery, through Oct. 9: Tuesdays through Sundays, 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. Free tours Saturdays and Sundays at 1 p.m.; meet at the Visitors Center. Admission: $3; $1.50 for students and the elderly; free for children 15 and under; free on Tuesdays, except holidays; free from 10 a.m. to noon on Saturdays. Hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, 8 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Saturdays, Sundays and holidays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; beginning in October, hours are Tuesdays through Fridays, 8 a.m. to 4:30 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays and holidays, 10 a.m. to 4:30 p.m. The conservatory closes 30 minutes before the grounds. Information: (718) 623-7200.

STATEN ISLAND BOTANICAL GARDEN, 1000 Richmond Terrace, Livingston. The garden covers 83 acres. Hours: daily, dawn to dusk. Free admission to the grounds. The one-acre New York Chinese Scholars' Garden is open. ''China: Ancient Art and Sciences,'' featuring 13 artisans from China demonstrating their craft and 300 works of art; through Sunday. ''Connie Gretz's Secret Garden,'' a walled garden with a formal maze, including a castle and a moat drawbridge, adjacent to the New York Chinese Scholars' Garden, with the same hours. Admission to the ''Secret Garden,'' $2 adults, $1 a child; adults are free with a child. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission to the Chinese Scholars' Garden: $7.50; $5 for the elderly and students and children under 12; under 1, free. After Sunday, admission: $5; $3 for students, the elderly and children under 12; under 1, free. Information: (718) 273-8200.
ON THE STREET
KOREAN-AMERICAN PARADE, Broadway, from 43rd to 23rd Streets. Sunday at noon.
PULASKI DAY PARADE, Fifth Avenue, from 26th to 51st Streets. Sunday at 12:30 p.m.
AMSTERDAM AVENUE FALL FAIR, from 96th to 119th Streets. With entertainment, arts and crafts, and food. Tomorrow, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Sponsored by the Valley Restoration Business Improvement District.
''N.Y.C. OKTOBERFEST,'' Third Avenue, from 42nd to 57th Streets, Manhattan. Sunday, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Sponsored by Cathedral High School.

FEAST OF ST. FRANCIS, Cathedral of St. John the Divine, 1047 Amsterdam Avenue, at 112th Street, Morningside Heights. Sunday. An 11 a.m. service followed by a blessing of the animals at 1 p.m. and a street fair that lasts until 5 p.m. Admission is free to the 11 a.m. service but tickets are required and can be picked up at the cathedral at 9 a.m. Information: (212) 316-7540.
WALKING TOURS

''THE FLATIRON DISTRICT: MADISON SQUARE PARK AND ENVIRONS,'' Manhattan. An architectural and historical tour that includes statuary. Meets today at 11 a.m. at the northwest corner of Park Avenue South and 23rd Street. Sponsored by the Municipal Art Society. Fee, $10; $8 for students, the elderly and society members. Information: (212) 935-3960.

''FOOD: OFF THE BEATEN PATH,'' Greenwich Village. Combines tastings at local ethnic restaurants and specialty food stores with a stroll. Today through Sunday at 11 a.m. Sponsored by Foods of New York. Fee: $25 (includes food). Information and meeting place: (732) 636-4650.

''MERCHANTS, MAYORS AND MAGNIFICENCE: MANHATTAN'S CIVIC CENTER,'' Lower Manhattan. A tour that includes the 1812 City Hall, the Municipal Building, the courts of Foley Square, the Woolworth Building and the former Newspaper Row. Meets today at 1 p.m. at St. Paul's Chapel, Broadway, between Fulton and Vesey Streets. Sponsored by the Municipal Art Society. Tickets: $10; $8 for students, the elderly and society members. Information: (212) 935-3960.

THE BOWERY. A one-mile walk that will cover the area's rich social, theatrical and political history. Meets tomorrow at 2 p.m. at the Astor Place subway kiosk at Eighth Street. Fee, $10. Sponsored by The New York Chronicle. Information: (718) 423-8738.

''STANFORD WHITE: SPLENDOR AND SCANDAL,'' Lower Manhattan. Looks at the life of the architect and the buildings he designed. Meets tomorrow at 2 p.m. at the Washington Arch. Fee: $10. Sponsored by Street Smarts N.Y. Information: (212) 969-8262.

''JOE SENT ME: A HISTORIC SPEAK-EASY TOUR'' explores three former speak-easies in SoHo and Greenwich Village. Meets tomorrow at 6 p.m., at the southeast corner of Prince Street and Broadway, SoHo. Fee: $10, cost of beverages extra. Sponsored by Street Smarts N.Y. Information: (212) 969-8262.

''ELEGANCE AND ALE: A GASLIGHT-ERA PUB CRAWL,'' Greenwich Village. A tour of sites in the Village as well as the Flatiron district and Gramercy Park. Meets tomorrow at 6 p.m. at the Washington Arch. Fee: $10; refreshments not included. Sponsored by Street Smarts N.Y. Information: (212) 969-8262.

PARK SLOPE, Brooklyn, covers the architecture and history of this landmark district. Meets tomorrow at 1 p.m. on the southwest corner of Flatbush Avenue and Plaza Street West. Fee, $12; $10 for students and the elderly. Sponsored by Big Onion Walking Tours. Information: (212) 439-1090.

ALLEY POND PARK, Queens. A three-mile walk past ponds and trails. Meets tomorrow at 12:30 p.m. at Hillside Avenue and Winchester Boulevard. Fee: $3. Sponsored by the Outdoors Club. Information: (516) 328-8055.

''CHELSEA, THE FLATIRON DISTRICT AND HUDSON RIVER AT TWILIGHT,'' with an emphasis on the history of the neighborhoods with stops at the Flatiron building, the Chelsea Hotel and the Clement Clarke Moore estate. Meets tomorrow at 5 p.m. Sponsored by NYC Discovery Walking Tours. Fee: $12. Reservations and meeting place: (212) 465-3331.

''OLD AND NEW MONEY: THE ORIGINS OF CENTRAL PARK WEST AND FIFTH AVENUE.'' How the architecture reflects the history of its early communities, with stops at the Harry Sinclair and Henry Frick mansions, the Dakota and the Prasada. Tomorrow at 2 p.m. and Sunday at 1:30 p.m. Fee: $12. Sponsored by NYC Discovery Walking Tours. Reservations and meeting place: (212) 465-3331.

SUTTON-BEEKMAN PLACE-TURTLE BAY: ''FROM BETTER TO BEST'' explores the Manhattan neighborhoods of the rich and famous. Meets Sunday at 2 p.m. on the northeast corner of First Avenue and 59th Street. Fee: $10. Sponsored by Bernie's New York. Information: (718) 655-1883.

CITY HALL TO SOUTH STREET. Stops at a historic shop and tavern, as well as the sites of political demonstrations. Meets Sunday at 2 p.m. on the southeast corner of Broadway and Chambers Street. Fee, $10. Sponsored by The New York Chronicle. Information: (718) 423-8738.

''MAGNIFICENT GRAND CENTRAL TERMINAL.'' Stops include Vanderbilt Hall, the east balcony and the former site of a newsreel theater. Meets Sunday at 11:30 a.m. on the northeast corner of 42nd Street and Lexington Avenue. Sponsored by Adventure on a Shoestring. Fee: $5. Information: (212) 265-2663.

''DECO TO MODERN: MIDTOWN ENTERS THE MACHINE AGE.'' Focuses on the architectural evolution of Midtown with stops at the Rockefeller Apartments, the General Electric and Fuller buildings. Meets Sunday at 1 p.m. on the northwest corner of Third Avenue and 51st Street. Sponsored by the Municipal Art Society. Fee: $15; $12 for members of the society and the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Information: (212) 935-3960.

HISTORIC LANDMARK TOUR, Manhattan, includes stops at Public School 158, John Jay Park and the Shively Sanitary Tenements. Meets Sunday at 1:30 p.m. at the City and Suburban Homes complex, lower-level archives room, 78th Street and York Avenue; a slide show precedes the walk at 1 p.m. Sponsored by Coalition to Save City and Suburban Housing and the City and Suburban Homes. Free. Information: (212) 388-0883.

''JAZZ NIGHTS IN HARLEM.'' A tour of the area, with stops at the Apollo Theater and Theresa Hotel, followed by dinner and a stop at a jazz club. Meets tonight and tomorrow night at 7:30 on the northeast corner of Lenox Avenue and 125th Street. Fee: $55. Sponsored by Harlem Heritage Tours. Reservations: (212) 280-7888.

HARLEM GOSPEL TOUR. Combines a gospel service and church lunch with stops at other historic churches. Meets on Sunday at 10 a.m. on the northwest corner of Lenox Avenue and 135th Street. Fee: $20. Sponsored by Harlem Heritage Tours. Information: (212) 280-7888.
